6 December, 1917.

Mr. S. S. Kwan 
39 Peterboro St.

Boston, Mass.

My dear Kwan:

My absence over the week-end prevented me from answering your

letter of November 29th and also I am to lå from catching a glimpse of you

when you were in Andover recently.

I am sorry erough that I missed you,

for it is a long time since we have had a good chat together. Can't you

come out again in the near future, anà give me a chance to make amenás?

Your suggestion about the Chinese plas is a most interesting

one. I feel pretty sure that we could get out a fairly good crowd here, 
up at the Peabody House at least, and in that way enable you to collect 
some thing towards your flood sufferers ' fund. I dian't realize that the

flood was so bad, or that it covered places like Teing Hua with which I am

more or less familiar.

Do try to come out. I want to talk over your own affairs with 
you, and also those of Tommy Lee from whom I have not heard for a long while 
and who apparently has given up the attempt to straighten out his finances. 
I dislike exceeding is to take the matter up with his father, but evidently 
I shall have to do so if I don't get some satisfaction out of Tommy himself 
in the near future. The matter has run on this way nov for several years, 
and I don't think that Tommy ºg Pather ought to stand this extra and unneces -
sary interest charge. Can't you come out in time to make dinner with me? 
All you need to do is to give me warning when to expect you. 
With best wishes, believe me always

Sincerely your friend,
